Well this is interesting, you have virtualbox modules loaded, I never managed to get KSP to run in a VM but [**Linuxgurugamer got it working in VMwarefusion**](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/92231-The-Linux-Thread!/page28?p=1758250#post1758250).

So I'm wondering if this might be a graphics driver error, and it can't handle the transition from the close-up orbit lines to the ones it uses further out, different shader maybe.

Can you try the open source driver with the VM? See if the lines work, though KSP may be too slow to play that way, if that does work there may be a newer (or older) version of the current driver you can try.

Failing that, you might want to give VMware fusion a go as it'll use different drivers to communicate with the host graphics card, or try a dual boot instead.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-07-18T16:04:56Z" title="07/18/2015 04:04  PM" data-short="8 yr">July 18, 2015</time> by sal\_vager**

That changes a few things, though it's still worth testing the open driver by uninstalling the proprietary driver and rbooting, and also trying the updated [**AMD driver**](http://support.amd.com/en-us/download/desktop?os=Ubuntu+x86+64) which is up to 15.7 now and is available as a .deb, so can easily be installed using Ubuntu software centre or my preference, GDebi, which can be found in the repos.

Also, if you have changed any of the default Catalyst settings such as anti-aliasing or forcing mipmaps, try disabling them.

When fiddling with Catalyst settings, I decided to update Catalyst completely. IT WORKED! I can't explain how happy I am now that I can actually go interplanetary again. wait, how do I start it with "LC\_ALL=C ./KSP.x86\_64"? I'm not on steam, and I use the 64 bit binary anyway.

You can do this via the terminal, it's easiest to just open a terminal in the KSP folder and paste that line into it.

Or you can make a script containing this.

    #!/bin/bashcd "/path/to/your/Kerbal Space Program/"LC_ALL=C ./KSP.x86_64

And make it executable.

It'll start KSP and force it to use the posix standard for language, some system languages swap the , and . causing all kinds of issues.

Well, according to the latest dev notes, the whole 'what happens when you zoom in or out of the map' thing is being rewritten, so it should work in 1.1! ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif)
